raw_words: NA I am a current student of their MBA program with a focus on IT Management .
NA I have been in the IT industry for 20 years and have run several lines of business for the various companies I have worked for at the director level .
NA I am currently a director , and do make a substantial income .
NA I did my research , and am concerned about credit transfers .
NA Especially , since I am planning for a PhD in the future .
NA I went to UT Austin for my undergraduate BS Comp Sci , and I can tell you that the quality of education between CTU and UT is similar .
NA On campus vs . off campus are apples and oranges though .
NA Without enough time in a day to run a business and go to school , I was left with no choice but to take an online MBA program .
NA So , far I have been challenged and pleased with professionalism , content , and quality of the program so far .
NA It's just like an on campus experience . . sometimes you get really good Professors , and other times you get people that should not be teaching .
NA Over all in that aspect , the two types of learning systems are similar .
NA The biggest advantage I have found with online is the pace , and ability to attend on my time schedule .
NA The lectures are interactive and recorded .
NA So , if you can't attend you can listen in later .
NA Ever sit in a lecture on campus and wish you had a tape recorder ?
NA Well , with the lectures recorded online , if you miss something , rewind , and listen again .
NA Great feature of online classes .
NA There are some negatives , but they are minor .
NA Bottom line : I am getting my money's worth .
NA I have already learned a great deal , and the quality of my education is as good or better than my undergraduate on campus experience .
NA My $.02 ,
NA Despite catalogue listings , diversity of courses offered is poor .
NA Books were community college level or lower .
NA UMUC staff unprofessional and unresponsive .
NA Instructors dumb down courses to allow many to pass course in the open enrollment system .
NA Psychology courses are of very poor quality by comparison with other colleges .
NA For a program that serves a lot of military personnel , I didn't find degree programs that supported my military career .
NA Telephone calls and e-mail to Maryland personnel were not responded to .
NA That telephone just rang and rang and rang .
NA Other universities offered better choices in terms of majors , and transfer credit for military personnel .
NA So , eventually I went with another program .
NA I think one can only suck it up and drive on for so long before getting fed up and moving on .
NA Sorry UMUC , you don't provide quality services for the money you expect .
NA Let Me Admit first off : Devry U Should adopt a stricter Admittance policy .
NA With A GOOD GPA you will be in demand .
NA Dont fool yourself : ALL UNIVERSITIES ARE FOR PROFIT ( WITHOUT QUESTION )
NA I am currently attending Devry University and I am having a great time .
NA I am totally committed to this UNIVERSITY and my studies .
NA The classes are great , with a relatively small number of students per class .
NA The Professors make me feel like I am family or a good friend .
NA I attended Monmouth University ( Very Good School ) for a degree in EE many years ago before they dumped the program for Software Engineering ( EE was not making money for them ) .
NA I can confess that the difference is like Night and Day .

NA At Devry I get Lots of Labs to reinforce the theory ; at Monmouth University I get lots of theory but few labs ( I need Labs , I am not good with theory only ; I need to see the pictures , YOU KNOW WHAT I MEAN ) .

NA At Devry University the Professors go out of there way to make you understand the material giving you extra time to absorbed the concepts ( Naturally you have to show interest and willingness to learn ) .
NA Here is an Example :
NA At Monmouth University
NA I had 2 semesters in Digital Electronics and One semester in Microcontrollers w/ Assembler language ( Solid ) with 1 senior project for a Microcontroller Car )
NA At DeVry University
NA I Get 2 Solid Semesters of Digital ( Learned Twice As much including CPLDs and FPGAs ( mastery ) ) another 2 Solid Semester of Microcontrollers ( Assembler and C/C++ ) .
NA AND 4 PROJECTS ALONG THE WAY
NA All this in the first 2 Years alone ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! !
NA With More Microprocessors to come in the 2nd half of a Bachelors
NA This is exactly what I am looking for and maybe you are too .
NA ALL UNIVERSITIES ARE FOR PROFIT ( WITHOUT QUESTION )
NA Veterans Beware ! ! !
NA U of P does not work well with the GI Bill .
NA first , it took almost a year for me to start getting payments from the VA because the VA rep at the school kept " losing " my paperwork .
NA i eventually had to send it myself by certified mail .
NA and , because of the 5-week class schedule ( 6 for masters ) , the payments are not regular .
NA at traditional schools , you get a set amount each month you are enrolled .

NA at Phoenix , you do not receive your VA payments until after the end of each class , and it is pro-rated for the month , so you only get a partial payment , based on the time of the month you complete the class .
NA overall , the classes provide good information .
NA as a program designed for working adults , there is sometimes a lot of homework , and the instructors are hit-and-miss as far as quality of instruction .
NA my biggest issue is with the school's relationship with the VA . this has been major problem since I started , almost 2 years ago .
NA Veterans should stay away from Phoenix , as they will not receive the full benefit of the GI Bill .
NA while the VA says that it will pay up to $39k of my tuition , it will only actually pay a set amount each month , for as long as i am enrolled .
NA that amount is less than the cost of my classes , so in the end i will end up paying close to $3,000 out of pocket for my education .

NA the University already has an arrangement with the VA for verifying student enrollment ; they should also make it possible for students to get the full benefit of their GI Bill , and not be left paying thousands of dollars out of pocket .
NA I've had a great experience at UMUC .
NA Being a military member , the online classes take away the stress of full time job and F2F classes .
NA I didn't experience any bad customer service and was very pleased with practor exams which I had to take while I was deployed .
NA Online classes are indepth and the quality of the education is very good .
NA Anybody who thinks UoP is a degree mill simply doesnt know what he or she is talking about .
NA Those that complain the most are often people who attended other b-schools and think graduates from UoP are slackers and somehow lowering standards overall .
NA Uop is not Harvard , and none of us think that , but we also work very , very hard for what were earning .
NA The whole for profit thing is a red herring .
NA All schools are out to make a profit and none of them can operate without income .
NA I have finished 11 of my 15 MBA classes at UoP and I have a 3.85 GPA .
NA Although I know there are many other schools with stellar reputations and much higher standards , my life stage dictated that I attend a school that could cater to my work hours and pressures .
NA I would have never been able to get a grad degree while the sole breadwinner and co-parent to four kids .
NA Combine that with the fact that I am in my early forties and the possibilities for continuing education were very limited .
NA My job would never have allowed for me to take daytime hours to get an MBA and night classes are not available anywhere near where I live .
NA I wish I could have gone a different route but I could never pass the GMAT without extensive tutoring .
NA Also , after reviewing the substance of the GMAT , I realized that it would never measure ANY skills needed for my career .

NA As it stands , more and more respectable b-schools are dropping the GMAT requirement because theyre coming to the same conclusion I did , specifically , that the GMAT is a very poor indicator of who will be a good grad school student .
NA Pre-tests like SATs and GMATs are designed to be more exclusive than much else .
NA They dont measure a persons intellect , only what they may or may not have learned up to that point , but never what they are capable of learning down the road .

NA My SATs scores were very average but during my undergrad years , I went on to be a Phi Beta Kappa candidate , sit on the deans list multiple times , and get a BFA with honors from one of the most prestigious design schools in the world .
NA The curriculum there is affectionately referred to as medical school without the blood .
NA It makes top-notch b-schools look easy because there were no correct answers , only subjective opinions about students work .
NA I know tough , and UoP asks for plenty from its students .
NA I just sign up to attend next week so far I have not had any problems .
NA I just want to know if any one have there associates degree in health adminstration and how it helped get a better job ?

NA I have not been , nor will I ever be , a student at capella , but what everyone on this forum seems to be forgetting , or at least ignorant of , is the fact that the APA will not accredit capella so all of you out there who are getting the PhD in Psych , beware .
NA I am currently enrolled at UoP .
NA I am in my 6th week and I have learned a lot about Business Communication .
NA Before I got " accepted " my academic counselor went through the whole financial aid and student loan application with me .
NA Well , guess what ? ? ?
NA Apparently I didn't get accepted for either .
NA Fasfa didn't send a rejection letter and neither did UoP .
NA The only way I found out was on my UoP website , where it plainly states that I owe $4,000 for 2 classes .
NA My counselor will not return my phone calls .
NA I am a current UoP student in a graduate program .
NA I am roughly 4 courses from finishing my 2 year program .
NA The promise of the UoP was a great motivator into enrolling at UoP .
NA I tried attending a traditional university in the past , for my second degree , and it was too difficult given my work schedule .
NA What the UoP offers to career adults , with the promise of flexible education , is great .
NA The execution has been less so .
NA The deliver technology is good and has gotten better since I started in the program , especially with some of the materials and research resources .
NA I have the following issues : 1 . Quality of students .
NA I had student in my class who could not communicate and had little understanding of English .
NA Some students could not understand the material and had such poor spelling and grammar , that I could not believe they were graduate students .
NA They also did not work at the level of a graduate student 2 . Instructors .
NA Some instructors were quite poor , and do not supply lectures or proper feedback on work .
NA 3 . High costs .
NA Twice , I have experienced tuition increases .
NA Although this happens at traditional universities as well , the program is relatively quite expensive compared to a traditional university , which requires physical facilities .
NA 4 . Poor quality overall .
NA Too easy to get an A . You can slide your way to an A with little effort .
NA I purposely did not submit work , with the expectation that I would not get an A , only to be surprised .
NA Overall , I would not recommend the UoP for anyone at this time , unless the program and way it is managed changes .
NA The goals marketed to the public are correct ( flexible , adult education ) , but the corporate goals of the Apollo Group conflict with the goals of an educational institution .
NA It is possible to get some knowledge from the program , but this requires the student to read all the materials .
NA Otherwise , a student can obtain a high grade with little effort .
NA WOW ! All the negative stuff about CTU , amazing !
NA Listen , I am going to give all of you the skinney on CTU .
NA CTU is part business , part college , as is any university .

NA I would not recommend this school to anyone .

NA Give me a break .

NA Okay , I have to chime in here , b/c I see a lot of negativity out there :- ) I just received my Master's degree and this was the most difficult set of courses I've _ever_ gone through ( bar none ) .
NA I found the required discussion/participation in class very rewarding , as NO ONE can sit in the back of the class in this type of venue .

NA It is imperative ( to your grade ) that you participate in discussions ; there is a lot of knowledge and experience imparted in these discussions ; much more so than I would have received in a traditional brick and mortar classroom setting .
NA Why ?
NA For one ( that I'd noticed when we all got to Commencement ) is that most people were older than the typical Master's students at a BandM at a University campus . A lot
NA of these people are out in their field working already with a lot of real-world experience to give to the class . This is
NA just one of the values of UoP that I've gained . Some of

NA their stories and experiences ( and the personalities themselves ! ) I would have never met in my local University setting ( even though many of those people may have been from other parts of the country/world , too ) . The amount

NA of writing that one is required to do is also quite a bit more than a traditional school setting ( well , let's put it into papers/week count , because I'm sure that a traditional Master's program probably has one writing quite a few papers , as well ) . However ,

NA within the typical 6 week course , I'd say there were the 3-5 500 word essays ( the DQs ) per week , the 1000-2000 word essays per week , and the mega paper/presentation ( 5000 words/lots of slides ) at the end . On top
NA of this was the 50+ pages ( or so ) to read in our book , articles from the rEsource , and anything else that we could cull from the Internet , books , and articles from magazines , etc . All in

NA all , I feel that there was a lot of work and if you could keep up with it , great , if not , you ended up complaining a lot about it on websites , stating that UoP was not a very good University or some such nonsense . I will
NA agree , however , that some of the difficulties that people have expressed with the Learning Teams are true ( I experienced that throughout my classes ) . However ,
NA as a Master's candidate , you must recognize the fact that there will be people in your life who are going to fail and they will most likely be right next to you . The solution
NA ? Prepare !
NA When you
NA see a big assignment coming your way , just assume that _you_ will be the one who will handle the whole thing and when people step in to help out , all the better . You must
NA be proactive and step up to the plate with keeping up the work . Otherwise ,
NA it won't get done . Yes ,
NA this does allow others to ride your coattails , but I have found that those people did not graduate , either . I went
NA through the entire program knowing that I was honest about my work and turning it in on time ( and collaborating when/if necessary ) . The one
NA and only time that I let others lead ( my very last class ) was the time that things slid until the very last moment . I agree
NA that there is a somewhat inherent flaw in the Learning Team approach , but in the long term , the stragglers will not come out ahead , as they will not succeed . This *is*
NA how it is in real life anyway ( these folks get fired , can't achieve , etc ) , so why should it bother you , if you are a success ? David M
NA . Patterson , UoP MSCIS , 2005
NA University of Phoenix was a surprising disappointment .
NA As a working professional , I have two bachelors , I oversee multi-million dollar estates , and will spend 60 or 70-hours a week at work if the job demands it .
NA I'm not a stranger to hard work .
NA I enrolled and was accepted into the MBA program and was greeted by many happy , helpful people that went the extra mile to get me enrolled in the university .
NA Unfortunately , by my 4th class I was fully aware of a frustrating trend that my fellow classmates also commented on regularly .
NA The professors are more of a conversation mediator among the students than an actual professor .

NA Assignments were passed down , but when asked to clarify the assignment because the syllabus had contradicting , poorly worded , information , my professors regularly responded...."refer to the syllabus"....but wait , the syllabus IS the question .
NA It never seemed to matter .
NA The biggest issue I had with UOP is that the professors really didn't seem to care .
NA Students would be expected to post generally around 2 postings a day for four days ( 8-postings minimum , 200-words min .

NA per posting...and that's just to get your 2-points for attendance/participation that week ) ; in addition there were the normal assignments to complete as well ( anywhere from 200-words to 3000+ words ) , these could be work 7 to 20-points .
NA For a master's level program , I had expected and welcomed a heavy workload .
NA By my 2nd and 3rd class in the program , a 10-17 page paper wasn't uncommon .
NA The disappointing part of the program was that the professors would generally only mark your postings with a green S ( substantiative=good ) or a red U ( unsubstantiative=poor ) .
NA You could only see the professor's marks for your posting , not for anyone else's .
NA If someone posted something that was off target for the class , only that person and the professor would know .
NA It was very easy for people in the class to spend time reading and studying a topic that had no bearing on the intended class forum .
NA Discussions would regularly take side steps and stray away from the topics at hand .
NA If you organized everyone in the class by how much they contributed to the topic and to the conversations , the professors always seemed to be towards the bottom of the list .
NA I found that I spent most of my time learning from my fellow students .
NA The " real-life " experience of the professors were never passed along .
NA A standard response from my professors would be that of a sentence fragment .
NA Assignments and Discussion Questions ( DQs ) seemed like they were copied and pasted from previous classes .
NA The responses to the student's postings were minimal .
NA By the time I transferred out of UOP , I was posting between 15 to 25 postings per week plus assignments just get meet the requirements .
NA In a 6-week class , I only counted 3 comments from the professors directly to me and two directed to my team .
NA Who's on the other end " teaching " these courses ?
NA As for the program as a whole , it is organized in a semi-structured manner .
NA Finding your way through the site is above average and the tools provided ( such as the writing center ) are great !
NA The materials being kept online is a bit cumbersome .
NA Personally I like to have books I can flip through , highlight things , or be able to keep my finger on a page to flip back and forth as I dwell into a concept .
NA Ebooks , are less friendly in this fashion .
NA Plan on taking a lot of notes as your read or you'll be lost when you have to quote the text ( which you will regularly do !
NA Every week in order to get full points ! ! ! ! )
NA Now when it comes to the staff , they are very close to the same level as the faculty .
NA My academic counselor was nearly non-existent ; emails generally went unanswered or had a generic response referring to documents kept on the website .
NA Trying to get anyone to actually answer a question directly basically never happened ( staff or faculty ) .

NA When I finally decided to transfer out of UOP , I notified three people of my intention ( my academic counselor , my enrollment counselor , and my financial counselor ) ; not one of them has ever asked me why am I leaving , is there anything they can do or check into , would a different program be better , is there something going on in my life that is causing the problem , is it the university , would I like to put my studies on hold and try again later....nothing !
NA The only communication I had was from my financial counselor regarding the status of my student loans .
NA While the University of Phoenix claims to be a University , I never found the " higher education " there .
NA Before considering enrolling in the University of Phoenix , do some web searches for online degree programs .

NA Don't just go with the ones at the top of the list as they are generally the schools that simply put the most money into marketing their name ; as I have learned you don't always get what you pay for !

NA UOP is a sham - I took several classes - hoping they would get better but they never did - you post to bulletin boards - answer questions as if you were on some inane AOL chat room and 5 weeks later you get three credits .
NA I really think they should have their accreditation pulled .
NA I am a year away from completing my BS in Human Service Management and will continue on to my Masters in Psychology - all at UoP .
NA I'm giving it 4 out of 5 because I have not completed the course as of yet .
NA As of now I am going to a campus and would like to keep it that way .
NA There are pro's and con's to every and any school that you go to .
NA I ma only echoing what others have said in these posts .
NA As of now , I have had only one instructor who - although I liked him as a person - I felt maybe could have done a bit more as far as joining in the class .
NA The course material I feel is sufficient and I've yet to have any real problem with people in my team .

NA That's not to say that there haven't been the occassional bad apple - there has been - but for those of you you have been in a team you know that when you set up you team charter you also lay down the team rules .
NA With this school you get out of it what you put into it - like anything you do in life .

opinions.term: get out of it what you put into it

NA Many people are knocking Devry but I have seen them to be a very great school for people who really push themselves .
NA I've already asked my HR department if a Devry degree is credible and here was the answer : " If you earned you education , its credible . "

NA With further communication with my HR department I've come to the conclusion that if you didn't just purchase your degree but you earned it by learning and expressing your skill and abilities you and your degree are credible to any company .
NA If a company does not accept my degree , without seeing my ability I would not want to work for such a bias company .
NA Keep in mind my company is strict in every process especially being a Public traded company that complies with the all the public company acts .
NA The only reason I would see Devry not being credible is totally dependent on the student .
NA Its all on you , not the paper you have .

NA If I can get the job at college-graduate starting salaries , plus 3 promotions in a year without any degree from any school and just a dimploma , I know without any doubt that with a degree from Devry I can move around and have better leverage with other companies .

NA From what I saw and hear , you surely earn your degree at Devry , you must pass the class with a C to earn the credits , its only a year shorter than a typical 4 year program at a local college , and such a fast-paced career-oriented education is offered .

NA If you want to go to college to receive that " college-life " or to get the " personality " , " character " , etc that a college campus and life gives you then go to a local university or high-held prestige school .
NA But if you already know your career path , already have character and pesonality in your life , then Devry is a good option to consider .

NA I plan on going to their Keller graduate school to get an MBA after my bachelors because on year of your bachelors counts for one year of earning your masters and so you only have one year left to finish your masters !
NA I hated community college .
NA It was so bland and the classes were huge ( 30 students or more sometimes ) and the teachers were awful .
NA I've noticed that the successful students at Devry are brilliant , goal-oriented people and know exactly what they are aiming for .
NA If I end up having a bad experience with Devry , I'll come right back to this forum and explain why but I won't tell anyone not to go to Devry .
NA I had a friend graduate from Devry with a business bachelors in project management and she seems to be doing fine and is heading to law school .
NA It depends on your goals , yourself , your direction , your career , etc .
NA I just recently enrolled with UOP online , this would be my first experience attending an online course .
NA At first i was a bit apprehensive , but onc i got started it seems pretty simple .
NA I was not aware of so many horrible opinions of the university .
NA Which have me questionging if i had made a mistake .
NA Yes it is extrememly expensive , almost three times more than what i was paying per credit hour , so much that the military tuition cannot cover all of it .
NA I have noticed when contacting my councelor it is hard to get a hold of them , and when i leave voice mails i never receive phone calls back .

NA One issue that extremely disturbed me was just recently i received an email stating there was an error in my paper work and that i could not be matriculated ( i find this out now two weeks into my class ) .
NA I contacted the finance office the person on the other end was short , and pointless with responses to my answers ( i am beginning to wonder ) .
NA I have gathered the impression of the people in class as being fools .
NA It seems most of them are on there to get by and pay for their degree .
NA It sounds exspensively convinient , but it does not work for me when i need to IMPLEMENT my skills .
NA I am going to continue in my undergraduate program and continue to carefully examin the quality of my experience at UOP online .
NA For now i have had a somewhat decent experience , concerning at one point but decent for the moment .
NA More posts to come .
NA While I'm not a CTU student , I work with four people who are .
NA In one case , a coworker is about to graduate with a software engineering degree .
NA Not only can he not write a single line of code but , yesterday he asked me what a " text editor " was .
NA I have no formal computer related education nor do I consider myself particularly computer literate however , I can answer all of his computer related questions correctly .
NA Yet another coworker completed a CTU software engineering masters and has almost no understanding of computers beyond that of a typical computer user .
NA How can this school be accredited ?
NA Even though I work with CTU students , my employer is a federal technical contractor and explicitly does not hire employees with CTU degrees .
NA All you have submitted are accusations that have not went forth to determine CTU as an unfit educational institution .
NA Walmart and Home Depot have accusations applied to them almost on a daily basis .
NA We can't stop venture capitalist or investment firms from purchasing what they think is an investment .
NA This is why we have checks and balances including government oversight .
NA Anyone can accuse someone for something . . . .
NA I have recently enrolled in UOP online/flexnet .
NA The experience is a joke .
NA I am pursuing an accounting degree and have attended community college for two years .
NA THe first class is a breeze just to get you used to the format of the class .
NA I checked on my next 3 classes and there was absolutely nothing relevant to accounting besides the importance and history .
NA The textbooks I read through reminded me of a history or english class .
NA Anybody who takes the time to do the work will get an A . Grades should be determined by attendance , effort , and skills learned .
NA Not attendance and effort .

NA Learning to write essays on the importance of accounting is ridiculous , and I believe that a person who hopes to gain knowledge of accounting and be able to have a career in the accounting field should steer clear of UOP .
NA UOP disgraces academics by collecting tuition from students and giving useless information for working adults which will only teach the adults how to write reports .
NA UOP provides you all the tools to obtain your degree .
NA Yes , there are some people in the classes that do not belong there .
NA Yes , there are some instructors that appear unqualified to teach at a college-level .
NA The school is not perfect .
NA Who knew ?
NA Personally , I have been relatively pleased with my experience at UOP .
NA I have found it to be more difficult than attending traditional classes .
NA They really load you down with work to justify giving you credit hours .
NA Also , learning is easier for me in a physical classroom environment .
NA I like the face-to-face interaction with the class and instructor .
NA However , I have made the experience work for me .
NA The people that have degraded the degree have their reasons I suppose .
NA Prior to attending the college , I made phone calls to businesses to ask for opinions of online degrees .
NA The fact that I will have an online degree does not disqualify me from an interview .
NA My work experience , how I interview , and my desire to succeed is what hiring managers care about .
NA In todays world , those are the things that are important .
NA Weaknesses in one of those areas can easily be overlooked because of the strengths in the other two .
NA The college is what you make of it .
NA People can complain about their experiences if they want .
NA Other people can say UOP is the best school for anyone wanting a degree to attend .
NA The fact of the mater is this , you can achieve the same goal by taking other avenues .
NA Most companies will not be impressed by an UOP degree .
NA Most companies will not be unimpressed by an UOP degree .
NA The important thing is that you get an education .
NA How you use that education and succeed in life depends on you .
NA I have to give UOP a four star rating .
NA I am graduating in May with by BIS degree and have a great experience with them .

NA I have learned more than I ever learned at my traditional school where I earned my A.S . I have done more work and retained more knowledge studying at UOP five hundred times more than I did at the other University's and Community Colleges I have attended .
NA I think some people don't like to accept the fact that learning can be done via the Internet and satellite classrooms .
NA IT is strange though because they are probably the same people who are setting up web training and surveys within their company's .

NA It may be hard to accept for some but it is a growing discovery that humans are capable of learning without being hand fed the answers to everything ; we can be self-motivated and self-disciplined to the point of actually learning without an instructors face to their name or ever setting foot in a four walled room but in the convenience of our own offices and homes .
NA I would have never had the chance to further my education if I had to attend a ground campus for all my classes .
NA I have a son , husband , home , full-time job and life to live .
NA I only have the wee hours of the night to study and attend class and traditional schools do not offer this flexibility .
NA I read all the bad comments about the school and it saddens me .
NA I am sure that people have had bad experiences at UOP but students have had bad experiences at every school .
NA Schedules change , instructors stink , prices rise , etc .
NA I know the future will only be filled with more students graduating from schools that have flexible schedules and advanced technology that allows them to provide such an atmosphere .
NA If traditional schools do not jump on the bandwagon they may find themselves short a few students .
NA Anyway , I loved my experience and my employer is SO happy for me to be graduating and they support UOP degrees 100% .
NA I will no longer be passed up for a promotion due to not having a degree .
NA I am more educated and confident now and when I encounter someone who disagrees I will never cower away but stand up for my degree and what I have learned .
NA I graduated with a degree in business ( MBA ) and I have to say this their faculty is top ranked .
NA They have been very supportive and attentive to my progress .
NA Unlike with more old fashioned schools , instructors don't teach as much as they facilitate information and provide feedback to each student's research and interpretation of learned materials .
NA They also help you tie all learned materials to your current job and work experience .
NA I've found that they are a great asset to network with too .
NA At Capella , financial aid was a snap !
NA The community of students is also awesome and I've been able to network with many of them .
NA The coursework is challenging and you will get what you put into it .
NA I loved Capella and I hope that they continue their good job .
NA I am an Elementary Ed student with Saint Leo University at one of the satelite campuses .
NA Overall my experience with the teachers has rated a 5 out of 5 . The instruction has been wonderful .
NA The Academic Advisor has always been willing to listen and she is an exceptional administrator .
NA However , One particular ( adjunct ) instructor is very limited when it comes to using a computer and her evaluations and comments are not consistant .
NA She does not seem to be able to work with students who have disabilitys .
NA I have had great reveiws up until now and may not graduate because one observer has thrown a wrench in things .
NA It is scary to think that you can work hard for four years only to have one person ruin it for you .

NA I would reccomend anyone taking Elementary Education to think twice about taking it at a satelite campus or at least request an observer who is competent if they are uncomfortable with the person observing them .

NA However , The teachers are outstanding and the instruction and assessment is fair.Saint Leo truly cares about its students but will not admit or send another observer if you request one to get a second opinion .
NA It is not worth the expense to go into elementary education if you can lose it all at the last minute .
NA You would be better off getting a degree in another feild and then applying for certification with the Department of Education .
NA Northcentral has a great doctor of education program .
NA It encompasses many disciplines and works well with my schedule .
NA The constant negative controversy surrounding Capella and other institutions of this type is deserved .
NA They are not really " non traditional " excellent institutions as much as they are advertising savvy businesses .

NA They seek out and use four types of students : 1 ) students who are not very adept at finding good institutions , 2 ) students who doubt their own abilities , 3 ) student who cannot overcome the psychological barrier of being outside of perceived mainstream systems , and students who want a simple way out of the challenge of good competitive educational excellence .
NA These people are great sitting ducks for trashy institutions like Capella that are really all about misuse of government loan funding .
NA When Cappella's low rent degrees are exposed to hiring entities aware of good education practices , they do not hire these so called degreed graduates .

NA I recently was involved in a conversation at work where a Capella PH D student was so ashamed of the school for his " in progress " degree that he did not want to mention the name of the institution to the group .
NA When they , in error , thought he was at the University of Arizona and were impressed , he just let them think that , turned red , and left the conversation as soon as possible .
NA Knowing that he was in the Cappella program and then seeing his embarrassment said volumes .
NA There are many mainstream online classes through good universities .
NA Capella is a disgrace and people who enroll there are fooling themselves .
NA There are always lucky people who will get ahead with any degree .
NA Capella is a junk degree sold to a disenfranchised group who are looking for a Ph D in all the wrong places .
NA PhD's from Capella are the equivalent of a medical degree from a Wal-Mart pharmacy .
NA People who have PH D's from Capella are academic QUACKS...and perceived as such by people who know higher education .
NA I attend CTU and it is an excellent school .
NA I have attended a campus based school and didn't learn nearly as much as I am learning now .
NA It is not easy to get an " A " especially in the Software Engineering program .
NA It is a must that you study or you will fail.I am graduating in June and Can't wait .
NA I already have a position lined up which pays $60,000 .
NA I am also about to be accepted into a great campus based graduate school .
NA Not to shabby for an online degree .
NA DeVry - Serious about Success , Not SEX .

NA So if I had a second chance in life , I would go to a community college , learn computer like the others , have alot more prettier girls in my book of love , still be skilled and certified in what I want , get a Tech job on the side and in the real world , and save that $30,000 I owe .
NA Who needs to know so much computers ?
NA Not even the POPE .
NA So , to put it short , if you go to DeVry , and focus on learning and not F!!cking , you'll have a great career , but also end up paying loans for 10 years that could equal a brand new car note .
NA Or you can enjoy life and see sunlight , have a wife and a girlfreind and some baby mama drama . . AMEN . .
NA I just started taking courses toward an MBA Degree at UoP , and I have to say I'm already disappointed .
NA I made the mistake of upsetting one of my , supposedly professional , professors and he took it upon himself to find reasons to second guess every decision I made .
NA I know myself , and I know my weaknesses .
NA I don't shy away from an opportunity to work on my weaknesses , but it's hard when you try , and the best constructive criticism you can get is " I don't like the way this is written .
NA Redo it and get it to me by 11:59 . "
NA That's not teaching , it's micro managing and helping others to develop a habit of regurgitation .
NA Anyone can feed you things to say in the form of " here's what I want you to say , and here's how you should say it " , but that's not the reality of a leading professional .
NA You will never get ahead by planning to say one step behind .
NA I've made the decision to attend another institution , and I recommend you do the same before you waste your hard earned money .
NA I was one of the early graduates of the UoPhx Online Program back in 1999 .
NA I started the 15-course Masters of Computer Science Program in early 1997 a few months before my first son was born .
NA At the time I had a BS in Mechanical Engineering from CalPoly and was working full time as an engineer to support my wife and pay the mortgage .
NA Back then we did not have broadband connections and the entire Online Campus required everyone to use a dial-up modem to connect and exchange information .
NA The Online Program made for great practical sense given my wife's pregnancy and time constraints .
NA I must admit that I had my doubts during the first couple of classes .
NA The use of teams with members scattered all over the globe made for some long nights and difficult coordination to complete the class assignments .
NA I also felt that some members were not pulling their weight .
NA In retrospect , the entire experience mirrored real experiences in work and life .
NA By the third and fourth classes I had hooked up with a core group of students who were also taking the program seriously .
NA Many others had dropped out by that time too .
NA The MSCIS program was probably one of the most intense learning experiences I've ever had .

NA Each class was six weeks long and consisted of group discussions that had required relevant DAILY participation in addition to lengthy textbooks , weekly college-level papers of at least 2000 words along with footnotes and mandatory formats .
NA The final projects usually were 5000-10,000 word essays that also required PowerPoint presentations .
NA The ability to communicate and write is ESSENTIAL for the Online Campus .
NA I spent many evenings at the PC way past 1AM .
NA This was not a program for anyone who wanted to slide by because the other students would rat you out quickly .
NA When I needed to take some time off after the birth of my son , the University was accommodating .
NA Financial Aid was available and was not difficult to obtain as long as you were diligent in submitting the required paperwork and followed up with your counselor .
NA In the end I completed my MSCIS in 27 months including a 12 week break to be a Dad .
NA I had a GPA of 3.9 for the program .
NA I was able to shift departments within my company and increase my salary by 50% .
NA I also had many opportunities and projects presented to me because I had both Mechancal and IT skills .
NA First of all , I only gave UOP a " 1 " because there was a " 0 " as an option .
NA The experience at UOP has been nothing but a hassle .
NA The staff is extremely unprofessional and unorganized .
NA My story is one that has probably happened to other people , and it involves financial aid , or lack there of .
NA I recently left the military and began using my G.I Bill for college .
NA When I enrolled , I opted to use my military money to pay for classes , but signed up for financial aid to defer the payment until my G.I . Bill took affect .
NA When my government money began to come in , I called the university to see what needed to be done .
NA I was told multiple times that because I was approved for aid through the university , the G.I . Bill money was mine to keep for personal use , and I was covered for eight classes .
NA After being told this several times , I thought that things were in order .
NA WRONG !
NA I was recently handed a bill of almost $6,000.00 .
NA The woman responsible for this was apparently discharged from the university , but they will not take the hit for this terrible mistake .

NA So , after hearing negative stories about some of their programs not being accredited , and actually reading on the internet that they do not offer accredited online courses , degrees , or programs , this has shown me that the University of Phoenix is nothing more than a criminal hoax .
NA Everyone , do yourselves a favor and do not even entertain the thought of attending this apparent college .

NA As a very short lived former student with Western International University let me say the following : ( a ) the school is a joke ( but then again it's an heir of the UOP ; ( b ) Financial Aid is truly a joke ; ( c ) My enrollment Advisor is nowhere to be found ; ( d ) I have been told nothing but " unusual " lies I've never heard of in an educational environment ; ( e ) They talk a good game until they get you in and then they think they have you hooked ; ( f ) It took darned near 4 weeks into a 9 week program before my academic advisor contacted me ; ( g ) They literally provide you with the paperwork which clearly implicates their " unusual " practices ; ( h ) They assume you know no better than to believe their B.S . ; ( i ) I reported them to a division of the DOE inturn , the DOE representatives have contacted the Financial Aid Office of Theft on several occasions regarding my case .
NA To date , The Financial Aid Office of Theft has not returned any of their phone calls .
NA Go figure .
NA My next step is to file a complaint thru the Arizona Attorney General's Office based on Theft By Deception , Negligence and a few other choice words .
NA Both institutions should be drawn and quartered for the numerous violations students have brought to the attention of the DOE and whomever else .
NA You know a problem exists when EMPLOYEES post negative feedback about their employer .
NA Take a hint : Find another online school to devote your time and hard earned money too or else you too will be SCREWED over many times .
NA I received a Ph . D . from Capella University .
NA Compared with others with whom I am acquainted who earned their doctoral degrees from brick-and-mortars , the education I received was vastly superior .
NA I highly recommend Capella to bright , motivated , self-starters who enjoy learning , researching and writing .

NA I attended a traditional college for my BS and tried to continue that with my MS ( few years separation there ) , but with work , wife and kids it became difficult in terms of time driving , taking notes in class , etc .
NA Its now been 5 years since I graduated from UoP and I have to say it has help me get promoted .
NA Most companies and government job want you to have have a MS degree for management jobs , but as long as they are accredited they hold value .
NA My 3 years getting the degree was not easy spending on avg 20 hours per week on discussions , homework , papers and group assignments .
NA ( Traditional classes you dont get this type of experience ) .

NA You do learn since it forces you to read ( and write alot ) the textbooks that come with each class and ability to ask questions to your instructor and/or fellow students when you dont understand .
NA Iam speaking from experience here and UoP has helped me in my career and you do learn new things .
NA Its better than not doing nothing if you continue to go to traditional colleges but never seem to finish because of your business schedule .
NA I graduated from AIU online with a BIT Programming .
NA I decided to finish my education with a online school after 8 years of attending a State Uni .

NA I had a serious problem with the state uni , I was never able to get into any of my classes , due to time constraints , I worked fulltime all the way through school , and because freshman had priority on all GE classes .
NA What this equaled was 8 years of college , all GEs except math complete and my major classes were never scheduled so I could attend .
NA I ended up taking 2 classes a semester because I due to the state colleges bureaucracy I was never able to find or enroll in classes that would work with a fulltime schedule .

NA My biggest fear was that if I ever finished school I would never even use my degree , after all , at the time I was working in a retail store with several college grads doing the same thing as me .
NA I entered AIU with a beginners level in computers .
NA I had worked with some programming but not much .
NA The classes were laid out in a progressive manner , as with math you need to have a foundation before you can start building on it and AIU took this into account .
NA My instructors were well versed in the subjects they taught and had just as many if not more office hours than , my State Uni , that they could be approached for help .
NA Because it is an accelerated program the classes move fast and it is very easy to fall behind .
NA If you are considering AIU you will need to be ready to apply yourself in order to get the work done , because no room for procrastinators here !
NA The course work was very challenging and I really walked away from this school with an education I can apply to my everyday life .
NA I am even working a job now where I use skills that are directly related to my degree and lessons I learned at AIU .
NA How many other people can say that as well ?
NA I just finished my Bachelor of Science/Business Management at UOP and I am now getting ready to start the MBA program at UOP .
NA I started as a junior having gone to community college prior .
NA The 22 months that it took me on ground were the best times of my life .

opinions.term: the best times of my life

raw_words: NA The Sacramento Valley campus has some of the most remarkable instructors I have ever had .
NA I have 18 years of work experience in my field and the learning environment that University of Phoenix provides is far more relative to business than a traditional college .
NA The students not only have to learn to work together in teams , but also learn how to present learned material .
NA The students get the opportunity to be good at public speaking .

NA Compared to the traditional " cram for exams " , the UOP student must learn the material enough to present in front of the class ; not to mention the many , many research papers that are required in each of the courses .
NA As a hiring manager , I would lean more toward someone with a degree from University of Phoenix than one from a state university .
NA I'm just starting at DeVry Online in WA state .
NA I've had a great experience so far .
NA I really like that my advisor ACTUALLY CARES about my success and always keeps me up to date , and even calls occasionally to check in and make sure I'm still on track .
NA My Community College credits transferred just fine , I entered DeVry as a high sophomore .
NA The financial aid office has been extremely helpful .

NA Here is some REAL ADVISE : Those of you who say DeVry's support staff don't do their job need to take more initiative on your own because nobody will do it for you , even at a traditional state school .
NA Whether you need help with $$ , tutoring , job placement . . . there is only so much that someone else can do for you and the rest you must do on your own or not at all .
NA This fault , if you have it , will follow you throughout your professional career as well ; I think that is why some grads can't find jobs , they rely on job placement services too heavily .
NA Don't blame your problems on someone else because they are just that - YOUR problems .

NA A word of caution to High School students : I am an adult student , I already have 5+ years of experience in my field and I only went back to school because I know for a fact I will be promoted to management when I get my degree ; I've discussed this path with my bosses and they are all onboard and none seem sceptical about the quality of education at DeVry .
NA If I was just out of high school I would not choose DeVry because I look at this school as a good place to CONTINUE my education .
NA If I was just out of high school , I would look to a more traditional school for higher education because with a bare resume , you want the best , most recognized school possible .
NA I chose DeVry because I work 40-50 hours per week and I can't attend classes in person ( there's not enough time in the day ! ) , and they also offer a degree that is very specific to my field .
NA The price was a little shocking , but considering my program is accelerated the cost is not as much as you'd think , less time = less money .
NA This is the right fit for me , but do your homework because it might not be for you !
NA Don't listen to above post .
NA This school is all about the money
NA The education is less than stellar for the amount you pay .
NA A community college offers better than this school !
NA Here you pay 6k a semester as compared to 300-400 at your local community colloge , 1-1.5k for csu , 2k for uc .
NA Overall most other colleges are cheaper than this school and offer you more .
NA I highly don't reccomend this school .
NA Most other private trade schools I would steer away from as well .
NA PLEASE , do not enroll in the University of Phoenix Online .
NA I wish I had read reviews prior to getting sucked in . . .
NA Sucking you into enrollment is just about the ONLY thing this school is good at .
NA I have taken 8 classes toward my B.S . in Business Management .
NA I will tell you firsthand this school DOES not care about your education...only the money you give them .
NA I attended Purdue University for two years , so I understand that going to a large college can sometimes make you feel like a number , but this is a totally different experience .
NA The financial aid counselors are completely inept at fully explaining my tuition to me .
NA I have NEVER been so confused by financial aid .
NA I have had 3 counselors since I started and lots of problems .
NA The only time I hear from them is when I owe them money .
NA Good luck trying to get someone to call you back any other time .
NA What they are doing should be illegal .
NA PLEASE !
NA I know you want to finish school and this appears to be a convenient way to do it , but you will only have more headaches , I promise !
NA I have been researching this school ever since I started having problems and there are just way too many students out their with the same claims .
NA PLEASE !
NA Do not waste your time and money !
NA I am now $15,000 into it , with one year to go .
NA I regret every minute of it .
NA You will not learn anything that you can't read a book at the library and learn .
NA ( I only give them one star , because I had to . )
NA I am a student in Axia College of University of Phoenix , and about to enter my second block of classes .
NA I must say that I was very skeptical of this school .
NA However , when it all came down to what I could do , UOP was it .
NA I work full time and take care of a child .
NA So , anything with a set schedule was out for me .
NA I spent months researching different online schools ( I'm glad I did because I almost called ITT Tech ! ) .
NA I used student reviews to make my decision , as students are the most qualified to judge .
NA When browsing reviews , please take time to pay attention to the grammar and spelling of those writing them .
NA This can give you great incite into how qualified they were to enter college to begin with .
NA Those who say that the grading is too lenient are right , but you must consider other factors .
NA Depending on your major , getting an easy " A " in English isn't cheating you out of anything .
NA In other classes , such as those that deal with specific subjects not studied in K-12 , you must study to get a good grade .
NA There is no easy " A " when dealing with a subject that is not used in your everyday life .
NA You must also be self motivated and willing to work .
NA Your teachers will not call you and email you every five minutes when an assignment is due .
NA Since classes at Axia are not like traditional class rooms , you must be willing to learn on your own .
NA While there are class discussions , the only way to really get anything out of it is to spend time by yourself and learn .
NA One last thing I would like to add is that I have never read a review from an UOP graduate that had trouble finding a job because of where they got there degree .
NA Education is what you put into it and the UOP is no different .
NA Some people need their hand held and will not do well in an independent environment .
NA What ever the UOP lacks in interaction , it makes up for in developing discipine , leadership and planning skills .
NA All undergrad degrees are about accomplishing goals and the UOP helps people achieve those goals just as much as any other school .
NA I have over 70 hours at " regualr " Universities and have found that UOP classes are just as challenging and provide the student with just as much opportunity to learn .
NA I EARNED my BSIT from Capella a year ago .
NA As it has been the case with every educational institution I have attended , I had good instructors and bad instructors , easy courses and hard courses .
NA I remember there were a few courses at Capella where classmates actually went crying to the administration about the instructors being too strict or demanding .
NA I encountered several students that actually expected a degree handed to them simply because this was an on-line education and they had to pay for it .
NA They are / were usually the vocal complainers about one thing or the other .
NA In my case , I did or I should say , my employer got its money's worth .
NA Like everything else in life , expect to get out of it what you put into it .
NA No more , no less .
NA All I received was a high pressure sales job , and trust me , I know what a hig pressure sales job is , I used to write the scripts for them .
NA I told my " advisor " that I was doing research on online education and 30 minutes later he gave me a deadline .
NA The next day he called me and started to chew me out for missing the deadline ? ? ? ?
NA What's up with that ?
NA For the next 3 days , his " supervisor " called me and tried to embarrass me into sending him an application fee since they had done so much work on my behalf to get me enrolled .
NA He insisted that i owed at least that to them .
NA I told him to sue me for it .
NA My Master's in Information Technology at UMUC stings as one of the great bad investments of my life .
NA The whole experience was so utterly fraudulent on so many levels .
NA But I was already invested in the third semester before I could no longer dismiss as flukes my astoundingly incompetent or apathetic professors .
NA Egregious plagiarism was the name of the game : Professors regularly regurgitate curricula and lectures from prior semesters .
NA Students merely copy and paste discussion threads into their own submissions , knowing their instructors award grades based on automated metrics like word count .
NA Power Point is considered an acceptable format for term papers !
NA No thesis required for a Masters degree .

NA And the anonymity of online study , already a huge obstacle to an edifying experience , is I believe actively promoted by UMUC for the simple reason that its impossible to criticize when you cant organize .
NA I recall one class in which our instructor logged in ( and this is not an exaggeration ) twice during the semester : once to greet everyone and once to collect our final exams .
NA Four or five of us managed to overcome the anonymity of our chat rooms to take action : a formal letter to the administration which went totally unanswered .
NA I guess what I find most depressing is the thought of people pursuing their undergraduate degrees at UMUC .
NA Having gone to a traditional University for my Bachelor's , I simply cannot imagine a graduate of UMUC's Web Tycho interface having experienced anything substantive .

NA And it may sound elitist , but it just seems depressing to think of tens of thousands ( a href=http://www.umuc.edu/ip/umucfacts_02.html ) of people walking around , thinking they've learned anything more than how to manipulate a web interface .
NA That UMUC is accredited raises some serious questions about the state of academia and the trend towards distance education .
NA And I do suspect that these problems are not unique to UMUC .
NA High-bandwidth distance education , through which real bonds , expectations and communication can take place , might work some day .
NA But the current state of distance education is just too shallow , but promoted by an educational system too strapped for cash and a community of working adults , too strapped for time .

NA UMUC's WebTycho interface is at best a pretend classroom with a few clever javascripts and java applets to entertain you while you wait months for feedback on that paper you're now starting to feel embarrassed for having taken so seriously .

NA You'll learn though , and by the end of your program , you'll find you needn't even bother buying the textbooks and you can get by with a couple manic hours of copying and pasting once or twice a semester .
NA Had an interview recently in which my interviewer said : UMUC , yeah - I've heard of them .
NA I see their ads on the metro all the time .
NA -but , I mean , is that even a real degree ?
NA Have noticed some others here are giving UMUC 4 or 5 stars - Don't believe them : This is a case of the Emperor's New Clothes if ever there was one !
NA I don't even bother to list it on my resume anymore .
NA ( http://www.epinions.com/content_145499459204 )

opinions.term: just in it for the money

raw_words: NA I took some classes there and was appalled at how some of the students in my " class " could not even write a sentence correctly .
NA If you want a degree just to say you have one , and want to pay big bucks for it , this is the place for you .
NA However , if you want any type of actual education , stay away .
NA UOP is a joke !
NA If you have any sense at all , do not attend this school .
NA The books they send are not needed for the classes .
NA The classes have no bearing on what you will be doing in the real world .
NA The instructors , if you can call them that , don't even try to present information .
NA The class I just finished the instructor showed slides and then proceeded to just read them .
NA If you ask questions , she just rereads the slide .
NA A lot of work for a worthless degree is not my idea of value .
NA If I could give it a negative star rating , I would .
NA What a waste of money !
NA The field reps ( some-most ) are rude and don't want to do their jobs .
NA Even for DE you still have to go stand in line for an hour or so to register for your classes .
NA Isn't this DE , DISTANCE education ?
NA I've taken 4 proctored exams . 1 of them was never sent and 1 was missing an entire page when received by the instructor .
NA Often you have no idea what your final grade is for a course because of these pitfalls until well into the next semester .
NA That can be rather depressing .
NA Don't even bother emailing the administration .
NA They won't respond .
NA UMUC brags how they cut breaks financially for military .
NA Their tuition is as high if not higher than that of a resident state universities .
NA Go to a real DE University , I am as soon as I find one that I like .
NA UMUC should be ashamed of themselves for even calling themselves a university .
NA I recently graduated from the UOP Pasadena , CA campus and was accepted to the Loyola Marymount MBA/MS Systems Engineering program .
NA If you can look past the study groups and manage the costs ( I am a veteran and receive the other 50% from my employer ) , it's a pretty good school .
NA I can imagine why many become disenchanted over the cost though .
NA Course workload is daunting , but you can't beat the flexibility .
NA I am currently working on a doctorate degree through UOP online , and it really fits my life .
NA Secondly , the classes are not watered down at all .
NA If anything , the classes can be extremely demanding for a working professional as myself .
NA I also get the latest information concerning the field of education .
NA In addition , I am able to learn about issues in education from various points of views through classroom discussions that occur online .
NA Up until now I was a big advocate of the way in which CTU finally started to get there act together .
NA However , recently in an attempt to pocket more money they have now switched all the students books to e-books .
NA They still charge the student the same cost as it would be for a hard cover .
NA Problem is this , half the time the books are not avaliable , you need to login everytime you need the books and half the chapters are missing .
NA The other change is these so called " Knowledge tests " .
NA These exams now are injected after each assighment .
NA They are tests that are suppose to test your knowledge of the topics discussed .
NA 'NOT TRUE " you will not get above a D+ on these tests .
NA They typically ask you questions that are not in the books , not in any of the teachings or anywhere in CTU's library .
NA CTU was on the right track but have now gone down hill .
NA Chatting with other students , many have intentions of dropping out to pursue other university's .
NA CTU gets a huge amount of money and one has to ask for what . ?
NA If your considering a online college , I would advise you to stay away from CTU , too many changes that are not for the good of the student but for the college to make more profit .
NA Sometimes I think they have these tests so that students flunk and then have to pay to take the course again .
NA Mary E . Peters
NA SECRETARY OF TRANSPORTATION ( University of Phoenix Grad )

NA Mary E . Peters was nominated by President George W . Bush on September 5 , 2006 , and confirmed by the U.S . Senate as the 15th Secretary of Transportation on September 30 , 2006 , after spending more than two decades crafting solutions to our nation's toughest transportation challenges .

NA Secretary Peters brings a unique perspective to her role as the nations transportation chief , having spent her career working on transportation issues in the private and public sectors , including leading both federal and state transportation agencies .
NA This hands-on experience allows her to understand and appreciate the real-life aspects of planning , building and operating transportation systems on local , regional and state levels .

NA Over her 20-plus years in transportation , Secretary Peters has earned a solid reputation as an innovative problem solver , a force for safety and a strong advocate for effective use of taxpayer dollars .

NA As Secretary of Transportation , she intends to use these same skills to tackle todays most pressing challenges including fighting congestion across all modes of transportation , improving safety and addressing strains on traditional sources of transportation funding .

NA She is responsible for maintaining a safe , reliable and efficient transportation system , while leading an agency with almost 60,000 employees and a $61.6 billion budget that oversees air , maritime and surface transportation missions .
NA Prior to joining President Bushs Cabinet , Peters worked in Phoenix , AZ , as the national director for transportation policy and consulting at HDR , Inc . , a major engineering firm .
NA She was responsible for building a management consulting practice and formulating public policy initiatives for the firm's transportation program .
NA In 2001 , the President asked Peters to lead the Federal Highway Administration ( FHWA ) .

NA As FHWA Administrator from 2001 to 2005 , she placed special emphasis on finding new ways to invest in road and bridge construction , including innovative public-private partnerships that help build roads faster and at less expense .
NA She also was a strong advocate for using new technology to reduce construction time , saving taxpayer money and resulting in safer , longer-lasting roads and highways .
NA From 1985 to 2001 , she served in the Arizona Department of Transportation ( ADOT ) .
NA During her tenure , Peters worked her way up through the ranks as a contract administrator , deputy director for administration , and deputy director .
NA In 1998 , then-Governor Jane Hull appointed her director of the agency .
NA While in office , she was recognized as the Most Influential Person in Arizona Transportation by the Arizona Business Journal .
NA Secretary Peters received the 2004 National Woman of the Year Award from the Womens Transportation Seminar , a national organization of transportation professionals .

NA She chaired the Standing Committee on Planning and the Asset Management Task Force for the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials ( AASHTO ) , and was a member of the AASHTO 2001 Reauthorization Steering Committee .

NA A fourth-generation Arizonan and an avid motorcyclist , Secretary Peters holds a bachelor's degree from the University of Phoenix and attended Harvard University's John F . Kennedy School of Government Program for State and Local Government Executives .
NA She and her husband , Terry , have three grown children , and five grandchildren .
NA Let this soak in to all who doubt the school ! ! ! !
NA My experience was similar to surprised's from June of 2007 .

NA I'm a somewhat embittered former doctoral level Capella learner who earned a 3.76 GPA through my masters with another institution , a 3.933 GPA all through the doctoral coursework with Capella , and who had no problem passing the comps at Capella the first time around .
NA What was my experience during the dissertation process ?

NA A lack of oversight from my mentor resulting in many mis-steps and dead ends , months of delays in the development of my proposal because of the same , and a continuously-frustrating lack of " connect " between the guidelines that Capella's School of Human Services provided at the time , and what my committee was even aware of-in the end I withdrew out of frustration .
NA I will likely always regret withdrawing , and I know I'll regret not earning my doctorate .
NA I honestly , though , saw no end to the frustration .

NA After it all , and as an educator in a public school district ( K-12 ) , I have a very hard time understanding how anyone could be willing to accept anything less than excellence from an institution that charges $50,000+ for an educational program .
NA If anyone has had a similar experience , please send me an e-mail at searchinglearner@juno.com , I'd be interested in comparing notes .
NA Instructors are not consistent from class to class on requirements for grades .
NA You will be in class with someone who can't read and write English and you get held to a different standard .
NA Class material is weak , instructors worse .
NA Screwed up financial aid .
